pr_title: ForwardedRequestCustomizer behavior should not be applied to requests without forwarding headers

timeline.message:
Issue #5443 - Forwarding Headers are optional

Signed-off-by: Joakim Erdfelt <joakim.erdfelt@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: why setting here and not below?
timeline.author: gregw

replies.bodyText:
The forwarded._proto tracking value is set from 3 different scenarios.

X-Forwarded-Proto: <value> header.
X-Proxied-Https: on sets it to https.
Forwarding: proto=<value> header.

So this one that you highlighted is correct.
The below action is to handle the not-quite-forwarding-headers oddball cases.

  
    
      jetty.project/jetty-server/src/test/java/org/eclipse/jetty/server/ForwardedRequestCustomizerTest.java
    
    
        Lines 731 to 743
      in
      0b646ee
    
    
    
    

        
          
           Arguments.of(new Request("Proxy-Ssl-Id (setSslIsSecure==true)") 
        

        
          
                   .configureCustomizer((customizer) -> customizer.setSslIsSecure(true)) 
        

        
          
                   .headers( 
        

        
          
                       "GET / HTTP/1.1", 
        

        
          
                       "Host: myhost", 
        

        
          
                       "Proxy-Ssl-Id: 0123456789abcdef" 
        

        
          
                   ), 
        

        
          
               new Expectations() 
        

        
          
                   .scheme("https").serverName("myhost").serverPort(443) 
        

        
          
                   .requestURL("https://myhost/") 
        

        
          
                   .remoteAddr("0.0.0.0").remotePort(0) 
        

        
          
                   .sslSession("0123456789abcdef") 
        

        
          
           ), 
        
    
  


Which has the ForwardingRequestCustomizer.setSslIsSecure(true) which should trigger both the proto/scheme to https and the request.setSecure(true) if the Proxy-Ssl-Id or Proxy-auth-cert headers are present.
Let me see if I can simplify this a bit.
replies.author: joakime

timeline.bodyText: I'm don't think that just because it arrives on the secure port is sufficient to make it secure.  Some ports might do both secure and insecure requests.
timeline.author: gregw

timeline.bodyText:
I don't think this match logic should be required.   There are many headers and some are orthogonal to others, so the logic below must be robust and can't be gated by a match, which may be for an unrelated header.
In the OPs case, proto must not be changed unless there is an explicit header that changes it - either giving a proto or forcing secure.
Perhaps this match is an optimisation to avoid several ifs below, but I don't think it is necessary as this customizer is typically only deployed when all request will have such a header.
timeline.author: gregw

replies.bodyText:
The match logic here (in jetty-9.4.x) was taken from jetty-10.0.x.
https://github.com/eclipse/jetty.project/blame/jetty-10.0.x/jetty-server/src/main/java/org/eclipse/jetty/server/ForwardedRequestCustomizer.java#L464-L482
The idea behind it is that if there's no Forwarding headers (even those not-quite-forwarding headers X-Proxied-Https, Proxy-auth-cert, and Proxy-ssl-id that ForwardingRequestCustomizer also pays attention to) then there should be no action taken by ForwardingRequestCustomizer, as the incoming request is not based on forwarding.
replies.author: joakime
